news uk-news queens-favourite-fast-food-revealed-"Foodhub creates the Maamburger in honour of the QueenByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The Queenaposs favourite aposfast-foodapos has been revealed by one of her former chefs - and itaposs not a McDonaldaposs Big Mac or a KFC bargain bucket.The -year-old monarch is known to enjoy the occasional potted shrimp and chocolate cake, but her biggest guilty pleasure is said to be venison burgers eaten with a kne and fork. Ex-royal cook Darren McGrady says HM prefers to flavour the game meat with cranberries rather than relish or secret sauce but never has it sandwiched between a bread bun. Instead, she eats it naked on the plate.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  Speaking to Insider last year, Mr McGrady said: “It always tickled me at Balmoral, we would make our own burgers. They would shoot deer, and we would do venison burgers.“There’d be gorgeous cranberry…stuffed into them, but we never set buns out. He went on to say: Her Majestyaposs Victorian upbringing dictates that the only thing you would pick up and eat with your fingers is afternoon tea. They would have burgers, but not the buns. So they would eat it with their kne and fork. The Queen holidays at the Balmoral estate in Scotland almost every August or September - last year for the first time in decades without Prince Philip, following his death in April.Mr McGrady worked as head chef at Buckingham Palace from  until , making food for Prince William and Harry, as well as Princess Diana. He also said the monarch hates pizza and during his time in her service, not a single pizza was ever served.  When he wasnapost prepping venison patties, the top chef was usually cooking up traditional French foods, he added. Following the chefaposs revelation in August, online takeaway service Foodhub created the aposMaaposamburgerapos. title: thousands demand 5ft bus driver
story: Thousands demand ft bus driver gets job back after she was fired for being too smallThe widowed mum-of-three lost her job despite being only cm shorter than the average UK woman. She has spent more than three decades working as a bus driver in ManchesterTracey Scholes was the only female bus driver when she began in ByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments Support is growing for a ft bus driver who was fired after  years of work - because sheaposs too small. More than , people have signed a petition to have Tracey Scholes reinstated to her job, after she was dismissed for not being tall enough. The -year-old became Manchester’s first and only female bus driver in . Sheaposs continually driven Brits around in the decades since, but recentlylost her jobbecause she lacks the “capability” to drive the new model of bus used on her route.Bosses at Go North West said that, at .mtall, Tracey is too small for the vehicles due to the change in position of the wing mirrors and pillar on the assault screen. The changes mean she would have to lean back to use the mirror, so her feet would be off the pedals. However, trade union Unite say Tracey has been “designed” out of her job. Speaking to the , Tracey said she has been struggling emotionally since. She told how she has been forced to “put everything on hold financially” and is now unable to plan for her future. Over the festive period, she did not buy any Christmas presents and today sees the deadline to lodge her final appeal amid a cost of living crisis. During her decades of work, she faced countless comments and sexual remarks and dealt with it all in a male dominated industry - with % of bus drivers being male in . Tracey was initially suspended due to her height but then later dismissed with  weeks notice. She has since worked with her union, Unite, to try and resolve the situation. Go North West offered her a new contract, but with less hours, and therefore less pay, than her previous work. She would lose out on £ a month. The widowed mum-of-three has said she has a mortgage and cannot afford to take a pay cut. Celebrities have come out in support of her including actors Maxine Peake, Julie Hesmondhalgh and James Quinn. And now a petition demanding her restatement has over , signatures. Tracy is smaller than the average height for women in the UKbut the less than cm dference has jeopardised her job.  Unite general secretary Sharon Graham said: Tracey Scholes was the first woman bus driver at the Manchester depot. “Her appointment broke the mould for women in the bus industry. She has given  years of unblemished service. “It seems inconceivable, that due to the blind intransigence of its local management in Manchester, Go Ahead is now ready to watch unlimited damage to its international reputation as a result of the tawdry treatment of Tracey.  “But that is exactly what is happening. From Poland to Turkey, from Norway to Indonesia, media reports have pilloried the bull-headed stance of local Go Ahead management. A Go North West spokesperson said Scholes was a valued member of their team and that they had made a number of proposals to ensure Tracey could still work, but that these were rejected. They said: “The design of the mirrors on our buses was agreed after consultation with Unite some time ago. All our other drivers of similar height to Tracey are able to view them safely. Dedicated, experienced, hardworking bus drivers are dficult to find and so we would never act lightly in a situation like this. We are sorry that we were left with no choice but to bring this driver’s employment to an end.” The company also said it is working to improve female representation at all levels, with a particular focus on attracting female bus drivers. The Go-Ahead Group have a target of raising the number of female bus drivers from % to % by . news uk-news three-most-common-mistakes-people-"Nadhim Zahawi says free lateral flows will not be scrappedByAntony Thrower:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsAn AE doctor has shared the most common mistakes he has found people make when taking lateral flow tests. Millions of Brits have made taking the tests part of their everyday lives to help prevent the spread of Covid infections. Dr Nathan, a doctor in London, says some people are testing themselves incorrectly and may be inadvertently going out while positive for the virus. He says the three most common mistakes are failing to spot positives, not reading the instructions and mixing up the best way to conduct the test, Manchester Evening News reports. Dr Nathan said: “Any positive line within  minutes, evenit is so faint that it is barely visible, equals a positive result, he said. “However,a faint line appears after  minutes, this can be ignored.” He added: “Don’t forget to avoid eating or drinking for at least  minutes before, to blow your nose and to wash your hands!”  “You should always follow the enclosed instructions, he continued. “If the test advises doing a throat and nose swab, do this. If it advises a nose swab only, do this. “That being said, there are some anecdotal reports of people getting a positive throat swab and a negative nose swab, and later developing symptoms and a positive PCR.”Dr Nathan who shares advice about Covid on his Instagram, @expedition_doctor. It comes as a new rule change is set to come into effect tomorrow, as the government works on keeping on top of coronavirus case numbers.There have been dficulties keeping track of case numbers in recent weeks due to shortages of lateral flow testsand polymerase chain reactiontests.Despite this, case numbers have remained high and have reached record levels since the Omicron iant took a hold on the country.  The UKaposs official Covid death toll passed , on Saturday January . Currently, people who test positive for Covid with no symptoms on a lateral flow test are required to take a PCR to confirm their status. This will change from January . They will still have to isolate for at least seven days, but only from the date of their positive lateral flow test. title: when to take pcr test
story: Situations when you still MUST take PCR test as major change limits number of testsA major change to UK Covid testing rules has come into force. Here’s everything you need to know about the rule change and when you will still be expected to do a PCR testA major rule change means fewer people need to take a PCR test to confirmthey are Covid positive Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika Padin:,  Jan | comments A new Covid testing rule has come into effect in England as of today, January , under which fewer people will be required to get a PCR to test for infection. Under this rule, someone who tests positive on a lateral flow test will no longer need to get a follow-up PCRthey have no symptoms of the virus. If you have a positive lateral flow test, you will need to self-isolate immediately. Since you no longer need to double check with a PCR, this means your -day self-isolation period starts earlier. If you get a negative lateral flow on day six and seven, then you can even end your self-isolation early.Despite the new rule, there are still over a dozen reasons when you still have to get a PCR test.  The government has outlined certain exceptions to the rule change. For instance, you should always get a PCR testyou have symptoms of Covid, regardless of the result of lateral flow.This includes not just the three classic signs of high temperature, new or persistent cough and loss of smell or taste, but the more unusual symptoms that are being increasingly reported.You should also get a PCR doneyouaposve been in contact with someone who’s tested positive, evenyou are fully vaccinated.  There are many other reasons to get a PCR test in England under government guidance. Hereaposs the full list:Youaposve been asked to get a test by a local council or someone from NHS Test and Trace A GP or other health professional has asked you to get a test Youaposre taking part in a government pilot project Youaposve been asked to get a test to confirm a positive result Youaposve received an unclear result and were told to get a second test Youaposre in the National Tactical Response Group You are due to have an operation in hospital People who are eligible for the £ Test and Trace Support Paymentwill be asked to take a PCR so they can access financial support People participating in research or surveillance programmes may still be asked to take a follow-up PCR test The one million people in England who are at particular risk of becoming seriously ill from Covid and are involved in new research of treatmentsThe rules and exceptions y between nations. For instance, in Scotland you should book a PCR testyou have had two or more void lateral flow test results. Similarly, in Wales, anyone who is in the clinically vulnerable group will still need to take a PCR testtheir lateral flow is positive but they have no symptoms. title: woman who shed 4st six
story: Woman who shed st in six months says weight-loss saved le her after finding lumpAndrea Richardson, , from Coppull in Wigan, Lancashire, was delighted to have shed the pounds through Slimming World - but was left stunned after she found a lump only revealed after the weight lossAndrea Richardson lost four stone after joining Slimming World Image: Lancashire Post   SWNSByDouglas Whitbread:,  Jan | commentsA woman who lost a staggering four stone in six months is claiming shedding the weight saved her le by allowing her to discover a cancerous tumour in her breast.Andrea Richardson, a -year-old Slimming World member, was delighted to have dropped the pounds through Slimming World but was shocked when she found a lump revealed by the weight loss.The mum-of-two went for tests after finding the lump and was diagnosed with breast cancer. She has since had the tumour removed and been given the all-clear. Now, she is crediting the weight loss with saving her le - saying otherwise, she would never have found the lump. The tumour was really close to my chest wall, so close in fact that it didnapost even get picked up on the mammogram,” she said. If I hadnapost lost all that weight, I would never have found the tumour as early as I did, and my story could have been very dferent to the one I am sharing today. Caught early, breast cancer treatment has a much higher success rate, so Slimming World has well and truly saved my le. Andrea, who works as a social investment Team Leader at housing group Onward Homes, made the decision to get into better shape in July . She said she had been overweight since having her first daughter in  and decided it was time for a change. She joined her local branch of Slimming World in her village of Coppull, near Wigan, Lancs., and said she was thrilled when she shed an impressive  stone lb. But in August , after she heard about a friendaposs cancer scare, Andrea decided to check herself and couldnapost believe it when she found a lump in her left breast. Within days she had received the shocking news that she had cancer. She added: It has changed me in many ways. I have more confidence and give priority to myself now whereas I probably didnapost before. I feel very lucky as it could have been a very dferent story. Women put it off, getting checked. Donapost. As it could have been a very dferent outcome had it not been caught as early.  I have always been overweight since having my first daughter, Elizabeth, in . When I had my second daughter, Isabelle, who is now , my weight fluctuated up and down - le makes you fluctuate. In July  I decided it was time for a change. The bigger clothes were getting tighter, and it was time to do something about it. Everything happened so quickly, I was referred to Lancashire Breast Clinic and before I knew it, I had been diagnosed with stage  breast cancer. Andrea underwent two operations, as the first one was unable to remove all of the tumours, followed by intensive radiotherapy treatment which ended five months later. She finally got to ring the bell at the Rosemere Cancer Centre in Preston on Christmas Eve  with her eldest daughter Elizabeth, , by her side. Andrea now runs the Slimming World group as she hopes to inspire others. And now, she has also taken over the running of Slimming World in Coppull as she wants to inspire members and make a dference. title: mans last words before going
story: Mans last words before going under for a pig heart transplant shared by doctorTerminally ill David Bennett signed up for the experimental procedure because he wanted to live and getting a pig heart installed was his only choice, and now hes awake and smilingDavid Bennett has become the first person to have a full pig heart transplant Image: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND SCHOOL OFByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A man who became the first in history to have an entire pig heart transplanted is awake and apossmilingapos after his surgery - and now a doctor has shared his last words before going under.Terminally ill David Bennett was told he had just months left to live as he had a heart disease but he was determined to survive so he signed up for the experimental procedure. He went under the kne at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore on Saturday, January , for a nine-hour procedure performed by Dr Bartley Grfith. The operation has so far proven to be a success, and Dr Grfith has revealed his patientaposs last words, which were: I want to live, andI donapost youaposll learn something. What do you think of the incredible procedure  Let us know in the comments...David, a -year-old labourer, was given the heart from a pig that had been gene-edited to make it more compatible, lowering the chances that his immune system would reject the organ. Appearing on ITV this afternoon, Dr Grfith said: He himself said, aposI want to live, andI donapost youaposll learn something. I wish we knew more but weaposre learning a lot every day with this gentleman and so far weaposre happy with our decision to move forward and he is as well, heaposs got a big smile on his face today For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Experts say it is too soon to know whether Davidaposs body will accept the organ and the next few weeks are critical for his recovery.Sparking to ITV, his son, David Jr, said: He realises the magnitude of what was done and he really realises the importance of it.He could not live, or he could last a day, or he could last a couple of days. I mean, weaposre in the unknown at this point.  In the first three days since receiving the organ, David has shown no signs of rejection.Mr Bennett agreed to be the first to risk the experimental surgery in December, hoping it would give him a new le. Mr Bennett decided to undergo the pioneering surgery on the experimental treatment because he would have died without a new heart, had exhausted other treatments and was too sick to qualy for a human donor heart, family members and doctors said.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news us-news mum--filmed-tossing-just-"Newborn baby thrown into dumpsterByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A teen mum has confessed to tossing her just-born son into a rubbish bin and leaving him clinging to le for six hours after fleeing the scene, police say. The little boy was found in a dirty, wet towel and covered in dried blood with his umbilical cord still attached, according to police in Hobbs, New Mexico.They confirmed a young woman, Alexis Avila, , confessed after being charged with child abuse and the attempted murder of her infant child relating to the Friday night incident, local site KOB reports.In CCTV footage, a white car is seen pulling up to the car park rubbish bins before a person in the back seat hangs out of the window to chuck a black bag inside. Around six hours after the suspect sped off, a group of dumpster ers arrived and heard a faint wail from the bag.  Acting Hobbs Police Chief August Fons said the little one was wrapped in a dirty, wet towel and covered in dried blood when he was found. The youngsteraposs umbilical cord was also still attached to his belly button, he added. The chief praised the group who found the baby for their collective quick response which saved his le. The groupaposs collective quick response to this emergency, including notication of , was absolutely pivotal in saving this baby’s le, he told Fox News.  The same camera that filmed the crime also filmed the moment the group, who have been called angels by local media, found the abandoned babe.Local site KOB said the CCTV captures the moment the witnesses start digging through the same dumpster and pull out a black bag before looking through it.Just seconds later a woman lays eyes on the child and opens the bag, retrieving the newborn and tending to it. Police tracked the number plate on the white car and arrested Avila.  According to reports, she said she did not know she was pregnant until last week when she looked for treatment for abdominal pain. She said the babyaposs father is a juvenile and she ended her relationship with him back in August. The officers also said she told them that she gave birth in her parentsapos bathroom and panicked. Avila allegedly stuffed the baby inside two plastic bags, one with other trash, and left it in the dumpster. The baby was taken to a nearby hospital after the rescue and later travelled by helicopter to another hospital in Lubbock, Texas, where he remains in stable condition. The police declined to release any additional information on the child.If you have been affected by this story, advice and support can be found at Sands . You can call them on    or email helpline@sands.org.uk. If you have been affected by this story, advice and support can be found at the Miscarriage Association. title: i gave birth toilet pull
story: I gave birth on the toilet and had to pull out my own placenta - Id do it againAlice Llani spent  hours in labour in her bathtub, before eventually giving birth alone on the toilet and then resorting to pulling her own placenta outAlice is known online for her holistic approach to motherhood Image: @aliceandfern TikTokByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments When it comes to pregnancy and giving birth, everyone has their own ideas of what they want. Some people want as much medical help and support available, while others want as little intervention as possible. Thereaposs no right or wrong way to have a baby.One mum, however, has left people equally surprised and impressed with just how independently she gave birth to her son, Fern, without any help at all.Alice Llani @aliceandfernhas gained an impressive following on TikTok, thanks to sharing details of her vegan and holistic lestyle and approach to motherhood.In her most recent clip, the mum revealed how she, not only gave birth alone on her toilet, but she even had to pull her own placenta out afterwards. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. When people argue with me but don’t realise I freebirthed my son myself on my toilet, resuscitated him myself, reached my entire hand inside to pull out my placenta, then bfhim for  months, she wrote alongside the clip. In another clip, Alice went into more detail where she explained that she actually spent  hours in labour in her bathtub, before eventually giving birth on the toilet. When pressed as to why she hadnapost opted for a hospital birth like the majority of first time mums, she said: If you manage to push a baby out laying down without breaking your tailbone tearing good for you but I’m not going to risk it. She continued: Things moved really fast when I was pushing baby Fern out. The labour dragged on for  hours but the pushing was fast. I’d been watching free births non-stop so when he came out my focus wasn’t, aposAh, I have a babyapos, it was checking up on him, because I was the aposdoctor.apos So I was looking for his colour and his colour was so good, but he didn’t breathe immediately. After Fern was born, Alice was really sleepy and was frightened she was going to fall asleep with her placenta still inside, so after trying all the natural methods to bring it out, she ended up reaching up inside and pull it out herself. Itaposs certainly not for everyone but you have to give her amazing kudos for being so brave and doing such an amazing job.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: man called kovid used love
story: Man called Kovid used to love unique name - now people think he changed it as a jokeA man named Kovid Kapoor previously thought his first name was unusual and cool, but he now finds himself the centre of endless jokes about the Covid- pandemicKovid Kapoor is embracing the unfortunate similarity between his name and the global pandemic Image: Handout AFP via Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writerTaniya Dutta:,  Jan | commentsThose of us with unusual names know that our monikers are like marmite - we either love how odd they are, or we canapost stand them. But one man has found himself experiencing both ends of the spectrum after the Covid- pandemic took him from embracing his unique name to being the butt of endless jokes. Kovid Kapoor, from Bangalore, Karnataka, India, always thought his name was special - until early  when he realised he now shares his name with a virus that has caused a global health crisis. The -year-old trip agency owner said: It is crazy how I am getting all this attention for my name.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Before the pandemic, Iaposve always thought it was a unique name. I have met just one another Kovid in college and we instantly connected because I never found anyone with the same name. Kovidaposs name was chosen by his mum after she saw it in a religious hymn and the word - which is spelt with a soft aposdapos - means scholar in Hindi. And although the pandemic has made him second guess his love for his name, Kovid says heaposs embracing the hilarity of the situation as best he can.  He added: I was amused when the WHO first announced Covid in . Friends and relatives started sharing the reports with me. It was surprising at first. For three months straight, my name was on TV every day although with a slight spelling dference. It felt great. My mother was equally amused. But as the pandemic spread, Kovid found that more people began to think he was lying about his name - or that heaposd changed it for a joke. In one hilarious instance, Kovidaposs friends ordered a personalised cake for his th birthday last year, but after thinking the message was a joke, the baker changed his name to aposCovidapos. The man has also had baristas in coffee shops stare at him bemused when he gives them his name and has been laughed at by security officials. He said: People really find it amusing, they think I am joking or have changed the name. I have changed my Twitter bio to aposmy name is Kovid and I am not a virus.apos Kovid is making the best out of the awkward situation though and hopes the increased interest in his name will help bring more traffic to the trip agency that he owns. Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: man slammed giving girlfriend two
story: Man slammed for giving girlfriend of two months ultimatum - him or the catA man took to Reddit to ask users whether he was in the wrong after he demanded that his girlfriend get rid of the cat shed just adoptedshe wanted to be with him Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsA man has been slammed after he gave his girlfriend an ultimatum - him or the cat.Taking to Reddit, the -year-old explained that he and his girlfriend Alice, , have been dating for a couple of months now.On one of their early dates, he recalled her mentioning how she wanted to adopt a cat, which he wasnapost too thrilled about since he thinks he allergic to them. Fast forward a couple of months, and all is going well between the couple. We are moving quickly because I feel like I know what I want and I’m not trying to mess around anymore, I want to settle, he said. But they hit a bump in the road when she told him her plan to finally pick out a cat. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. He continued: The other day Alice tells me she and her friend are going to a shelter and she’s planning to pick out a cat. I told her I wouldn’t want her to get one and she said she’s always wanted a cat and has planned to get one since before she met me. I told her it was so inconsiderate of her to get the cat because I am allergic and whatwe decide to move in together one day  I said I don’t see this working outshe plans to keep the cat. She told me I’m overreacting and we just started dating so I shouldn’t try to aposcontrolapos her and that I told her it’s fine so now she already has the cat. I insisted she take it back and she said she was not going to, so I said fine it’s the cat or me. The argument ended with her telling him that she needed space. I talked to a female friend about this who said I’m being [the a**hole] andAlice can apostake birth control every dayapos for me then I can apostake a Benadryl and chill,apos he continued. But when he confided in a male friend, he told him Alice is inconsiderate. Reddit users were quick to put him in his place, with many people saying that they hope she picks the cat over him. One person said: Youaposre  years old and have been dating this woman for two months... Two whole months to feel entitled to dictate what she does with her own damn le  Of course [youaposre the a**hole]. I hope she picks the cat. IT will be with her for  or so years. I give YOU about  more days. Another commented: Only reply this girl should give - aposSorry I think my cat is allergic to controlling men.apos Why do I get the impression heaposs the one moving quickly and sheaposs still in the aposthis is new and letaposs see where it headsapos stage  asked a third.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news my-mums-nursery-school-teacher-"Tiktoker reacts to mums list of preschoolers namesByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsYour name is often the first piece of information someone learns about you, which is why itaposs so important as a parent you pick a good one. But one woman couldnapost help but laugh when her mum, a teacher, reeled off the names of the children in her class. Shay went viral on TikTok after she posted a video reacting to names like Bram and Richard.Posting on her account, @shayymonet, she said: Another school year, another batch of names to judge.The first name, Bram, didnapost get much of a reaction from Shay. Bram  she said, to which her mum confirmed: Yes Bram. Bram with a B. Bram. Bram. Got it, Shay replied.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Then there was Emmett, Atticus, and Jordan, all of which got very little reaction. But when her mum says that one of the children in this yearaposs class is called Richard, she burst out laughing. RICHARD! Heaposs four  she exclaimed, to which her mum confirms with a yes. Her mum continues reading out the names: Annabelle, Adele, Alina and then Ryan, which gets a laugh but she canapost explain why. Then thereaposs Everleigh, which her mum says is spelt like Ever-lay and Shay says, Oh, like L-E-I-G-H...L-M-N-O-P  She laughs again at the end as she recalls there are kids called Bram and Richard. Since being posted, the video, which has been viewed more than . million times, has attracted more than , likes and , comments from people who shared their thoughts on the names. One person said: aposRichard  Heaposs  !apos No babe heaposs a -year-old father who came back for good measure. Another wrote: Bram is a very common name in the Netherlands! Does sound funny when you pronounce it in English though hahaha. A third commented: I used to think Annabelle was a cute name but the doll movie ruined that for me. Someone  said: Why is Richard so funny  I thought the other ones were more ridiculous. Others shared other unique names they had heard before, like Barnaby. One person revealed: At my kidaposs school, thereaposs a three-year-old called Barnaby. Who looks at a bay and thinks yes Barnby  My mum once had a girl in her class called STRAWBERRY, added another.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-convinced-shes-seen-ufo-"TikTok user mistakes a lamppost for a UFOByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A woman was left red-faced after thinking she had spotted a apos UFO apos - as when she showed the clip to her friends they pointed out that it was a streetlight. TikTok star Maddi, @daddi_bling, shared the video that she had shown her friends, explaining that she was at a beer festival and may have had a bit too much to drink.In the clip, they can be heard shouting with glee as fireworks are let off nearby, and as Maddi films she notices something circular floating in the sky. She then focuses on the object and can be heard saying aposwoah, what is thatapos, butyou look closely you can tell that it is actually a streetlight.What do you think about Maddiaposs incredible discovery  Let us know in the comments...Maddi shared the video on TikTok with the caption: And then I told everyone I knew that I saw a UFO. And over the clip, she added the text: Throwback to that one time I got so hammered at a beer festival that I mistook a street lamp for a UFO. Maddiaposs clip has been viewed over three million times in just four days, and TikTok users have flocked to the post to support Maddi, saying they would have made the same assumption. One said: Iaposm sober and I thought it was a UFO. And then a second wrote: Ok, but it does look like itaposs just floating there.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Then a third commented: No because I would have mistaken it for a UFO completely sober. That street lamp do be kinda sus though, added a fourth user. Other users said they had made similar mistakes in the past, as one added: Iaposve done this before. I looked out my car window, looked up and my heart sank for a solid  seconds. And a second wrote: Itaposs ok. One time I thought the full moon was so beautul and huge but it was just a Burger King sign.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-stitches-after-being-duped-"TikToker in hysterics after purchasing overly revealing dressByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsItaposs no secret that online shopping can be a little hit and miss. Sometimes items arrive looking exactly as described but others... itaposs a little disappointing.Sadly, one Amazon knows this all too well after ordering a cute little black dress from TikTok, only for it to arrive and barely protect her modesty. The TikTok user, who goes by the name Girlfriend online, bought a fullblack dress with a plunging neckline and extremely high slits up the front, which leave very little to the imagination. Posting from her handle @girlfriendxoxoxo, she explained: So I bought a new dress off Amazon. It looked really really cute online, but on me... I’m just dying. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. This is the dress. I’m laughing because I just can’t decide what to do. There’s not enough fabric here and there’s definitely not enough fabric here, continued, while laughing her head off. I’m giggling, sorry, because it’s funny to me - I have a very cute body but I’ve been duped by Amazon, dammit! Despite her giggles, many of her followers were quick to comment saying just how good she looks in the dress. That is absolutely gorgeous on you, one wrote, while another added: I love the way it looks! A third wrote: Itaposs such a cute dress though, is there any chance youaposd be able to tailor it ! Fortunately, the creative woman was able to find a work around to make the dress work, and ended up styling it with a gorgeous black corset on top and it looks amazing.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: italian prince branded stingy ex
story: Italian prince branded stingy by ex after though he showered her with lavish gtsPrince Giacomo Bonanno di Linguaglossa has launched legal action against Tanya Yashenko months after she filed a lawsuit against him - but the pair still spent Christmas and New Year togetherPrince Giacomo Bonanno di Linguaglossa with girlfriend Tanya Yashenko Image: InstagramByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan A legal row has broken out between an Italian prince and his girlfriend, who branded him stingy despite him showering her with lavish gts. Prince Giacomo Bonanno di Linguaglossa, , is believed to have met -year-old Tanya Yashenko, from Belarus, at a dinner party in . It is said the couple enjoyed a whirlwind romance, holidaying in destinations such as Monte Carlo, Dubai and the Males. The Times reported he also gave her a Mercedes worth €,, a €, share in a Rome bed and breakfast, expensive jewellery and €, to help her to rent a flat in the centre of Rome. According to Italian media, Yashenko filed a legal complaint against the prince last year, alleging that he was stalking her and hired a psychiatrist to assist with her case.However, newspaper Il Messaggero reports that the expert has now switched sides and accuses Yashenko of taking advantage of the psychological fragility of Linguaglossa.The Italian press also reportedly obtained text messages exchanged between the pair, where she criticised the prince for not being generous enough. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.According to the , Ms Yashenko said: “If you wanted to, you would transfer half your investments in Italy to me, but you’re stingy.The messages emerged after the prince launched his own legal battle against Yashenko last month, accusing her of “circonvenzione d’incapace”, an Italian legal term that means “exerting undue influence over persons who are non-compos mentis. It is claimed the prince was left traumatised after the break-up of his earlier marriage. Yashenko has denied any wrongdoing and has insisted that the prince withdraw his accusations. At the weekend, the Italian prince took to his Facebook page, where he said he wanted to “publicly apologise to my partner Tanya Yashenko for my  statements. He added: I would like to explain that jealousy is a big reason for my actions. But the gts I gave I don’t want back.” It also emerged that the pair spent Christmas and New Year together.But the princeaposs lawyer Armando Fergola told the: She continues to try to manipulate him. He has certainly not withdrawn his accusations and will not do so.“He is still very fragile and the love affair has clouded his judgment. The primary aim of this case is to protect him from her, both psychologically and economically. Getting her to pay back the money is a secondary objective.” Read MoreRead MoreFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Love" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news world-news newborn-baby-abandoned-egg-box-"Siberia: Newborn baby rescued from snow by two teensByWill StewartRussia Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A newborn baby abandoned in a cardboard egg box in perishing minus C cold has been saved by heroic teenage boys.Now the parents of one of them want to adopt the tragic girl as the daughter they had always craved.The child was found in deep snow by a remote road in Sosnovka village, Siberia, as Russians marked Orthodox Christmas Day .Renat Litvinov, , immediately called his parents who rushed to the spot in a car to take the tiny girl to hospital. Doctors said she was healthy and avoided frostbite despite the intense cold. The baby was in a cardboard box designed to store eggs and had been left to freeze to death, say police. Law enforcement are now seeking the baby’s parents and announced an investigation into the attempted murder of the child. “We were just out for a walk in the evening, when we saw a box,” said Renat. “We walked closer and heard a squeaking sound. We thought there were puppies inside the box. “But when we turned our phone torches on to see what was inside, there was a tiny baby - a girl. “She was lying there like a little doll, so tiny. “We were so stunned we didn’t even know for some seconds what to do, and where to run. “She had no clothes on her, she was wrapped in a piece of fabric, with a bottle next to her.” The lads tried to flag down a car - but no one stopped.  So Renat called his father saying: “Dad, we found a baby girl in the box.” “I rushed to them with my we, and took the baby to the hospital,” said Dmitry, . We were all shocked. The doctors had a careful look and said she was fine, not even frostbitten.  “My son and his friends must have picked her up just in time.” Medics say the baby - two or three days old - was probably born at home, then abandoned by the mother. Rinat’s mother Anna said: “We are parents to three sons, so having a daughter was our long-term dream. We are hoping we’ll be given a chance to adopt her.”  The Novosibirsk region children’s ombudswoman is backing the move. “We will be supporting the family’s desire to adopt the baby,” said Nadezhda Boltenko. Investigative committee operative Yekaterina Petrushina said: “A criminal case was initiated into the attempted murder of a minor.” Russian parliament speaker Vyacheslav Volodin said: “This story in Novosibirsk region didnapost end in tragedy only thanks to the care of the young men. “A newborn baby was rescued. She was abandoned by those who were supposed to care for her. “Instead she was left to die in the cold by the side of the road. “Were these lad not to walk on this quiet road, she would have perished from hypothermia. “There is no excuse for the fiends who abandoned the baby - this is a monstrous act.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesHospitalsSnowNewborn babyTeenagersPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: serial vaxxer 84 12 covid
story: Man, , has had TWELVE Covid jabs in less than a year - and wants moreBrahamdev Mandal, , from Orai in Bihar, India, signed up for extra Covid vaccines by using other peoples IDs and even managed to receive two jabs on the same dayBrahamdev Mandal, , said he wanted to feel stronger during the pandemic Image: Triangle NewsByAndy CrickLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA pensioner illegally booked himself in for  Covid jabs in less than a year before he was caught by cops in India. Brahamdev Mandal, , had all the vaccines in just  months and even managed to book two less than  minutes apart on the same day. The serial-vaxxer was only able to sign up for extra jabs by lying to health officials and using the ID of other people who also needed the lesaving serum. He said he wanted to feel stronger during the pandemic and rid himself of the joint pain he has suffered for eight years. The former postman has been accused of a string of offences by police in the village of Orai, in Bihar, India where he lives.  Puraini police station cop Deepak Chandra Das said Mandal was booked under sections ,  and  of the Indian Penal Code respectively. However, under section , the accused may get leniency due to his age. Among his jabs, Mandal got two vaccines inside  minutes on the same day at Puraini health facility on April  last year. The OAP bragged: I have taken vaccines and I recommend everyone to take them. Itaposs quite beneficial.  The Government has taken an incredible step as it helps back pains too. You should take it. My oxygen level has improved and I havenapost caught a cold since getting a jab. Mandal claimed he got nine of the jabs using his own ID card. Station house officer Das said: Mandal has taken  vaccines at dferent dates using dferent identity cards lying to the health officials. This act is a violation of the Covid- vaccination rule. He has taken vaccines between February , , to January , .One medic urged for officials to plug such loopholes. This is a massive loophole when it comes to the surveillance system. We need to plug in such loopholes, they said. story: COMPASSIONATE and dedicated, Dr Margaret Kerr’s work in Glasgow saved the lives of hundreds of premature babies. The consultant paediatrician at what was then the Royal Hospital for Sick Children at Yorkhill was a leading light in neo-natal medicine. She once said in an interview with the Evening Times: “I love babies – we are no longer just saving le but producing healthy future citizens. That gives us all pride and pleasure.”

story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: scottish government extends hardship fund for pig farmers
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: udny arms hotel being revamped by next door neighbours
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. title: aberdeenshire bins left overflowing due to covid staff shortages
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live.
